results.title: White House and G.O.P. Close In on Deal to Raise Debt Limit and Cut Spending
results.abstract: The details were not finalized, but negotiators were discussing a compromise that would allow Republicans to point to spending reductions and Democrats to say they had prevented large cuts.

media.caption: “It takes a while to make it happen, and we are working hard to make it happen,” Speaker Kevin McCarthy said of a debt-ceiling deal.

results.title: Chinese Malware Hits Systems on Guam. Is Taiwan the Real Target?
results.abstract: The code, which Microsoft said was installed by a Chinese government hacking group, set off alarms because Guam would be a centerpiece of any U.S. military response to a move against Taiwan.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: The Great Hall of the People in Beijing. Telecommunications networks are key targets for hackers, and the system in Guam is particularly important to China.

results.title: Australia Remembered Tina Turner With a Dance
results.abstract: The Nutbush, set to its eponymous song and sometimes considered an unofficial national dance, is popular with all ages and has taken on special significance after the singer’s death.

media.caption: Tina Turner performing in Sydney in 1993. Her ties to Australia extend beyond the Nutbush.

results.title: Oath Keepers Leader Is Sentenced to 18 Years in Jan. 6 Sedition Case
results.abstract: The sentence for Stewart Rhodes was the longest so far in the federal investigation of the Capitol attack and the first issued to a defendant convicted of sedition.

media.caption: Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the Oath Keepers, in 2016. On Thursday, he blamed the news media for demonizing the group for leading the Capitol attack.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Pop and Rock Music;Rhythm and Blues (Music);internal-sub-only;internal-open-access-search;Turner, Tina;Turner, Ike
results.title: Tina Turner, Magnetic Singer of Explosive Power, Is Dead at 83
results.abstract: Hailed in the 1960s for her dynamic performances with her first husband, Ike, she became a sensation as a recording artist, often echoing her personal struggles in her songs.

media.caption: Tina Turner in concert in Los Angeles in 1984. Her album “Private Dancer,” released that year, returned her to the spotlight after a long absence and lifted her into the pop stratosphere.

results.title: Surgeon General Warns That Social Media May Harm Children and Adolescents
results.abstract: The report by Dr. Vivek Murthy cited a “profound risk of harm” to adolescent mental health and urged families to set limits and governments to set tougher standards for use.

media.caption: Dr. Murthy testifying before the Senate Finance Committee on Capitol Hill on youth mental health in 2022.

results.title: Texas Panel Files Articles of Impeachment Against State Attorney General
results.abstract: The Republican-led House committee said Ken Paxton’s abuses of office rose to the level of possible crimes that warranted an impeachment vote.

media.caption: If impeached, Ken Paxton would be required to step down from his post temporarily while he faces trial in the State Senate.

results.title: Tina Turner’s 11 Essential Songs
results.abstract: Turner, who died Wednesday at 83, went from R&B shouter to rock queen to pop superstar. Here are some of her greatest musical moments.

media.caption: “We never ever do nothin’ nice and easy,” Tina Turner said on her introduction to “Proud Mary.” “We always do it nice and rough.”

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Music;Jazz;Folk Music;Movies;Lee, Bill (1928- );Lee, Spike
results.title: Bill Lee, Bassist and Composer of Son Spike Lee’s Films, Dies at 94
results.abstract: He accompanied a wide range of jazz and folk musicians and scored “She’s Gotta Have It,” “School Daze” “Do the Right Thing” and “Mo’ Better Blues.”

media.caption: Bill Lee in an undated portrait by his son David Lee, a photographer. Over six decades his ebullient string bass could be heard in thousands of live performances and on more than 250 record albums.

results.adx_keywords: Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);United States Politics and Government;Barnett, Richard (1960- );Trump, Donald J;Justice Department
results.byline: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
results.title: Jan. 6 Rioter Who Reclined in Pelosi’s Office Given Sentence of More Than 4 Years
results.abstract: Richard “Bigo” Barnett, who was pictured with his foot on a desk in the speaker’s office, had been convicted of eight crimes for his role in the attack on the Capitol by Trump supporters.

media.caption: Richard “Bigo” Barnett in Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office on Jan. 6, 2021. Mr. Barnett was sentenced to more than four years in prison on Wednesday.
